content.p: A collection of frequently asked questions that people have frequently asked me about SconeServer.
No particular reason, other than I like scones, and it seems to be a name that's not being used by any other company or product.
content.h3: What's wrong with Apache, IIS, etc...?
content.p: Nothing (as far as I know) - in fact I don't really know very much about Apache or any other web server for that matter. I wrote SconeServer for my own amusement, and not to try and improve on any existing server software. Having said that, I have tried to make SconeServer as efficient as I possibly can whilst maintaining a good overall structure to the code, so I hope it would perform reasonably well in comparison to other similar products.
You shouldn't - unless you want to. It's certainly not a good idea to rely on an alpha version working perfectly, as there will inevitably be some problems.
content.h3: What platforms will it run on?
content.p: SconeServer should run on any POSIX compliant system, i.e. UNIX and UNIX-like systems such as Linux, Open/Free/NetBSD, Darwin and Solaris. It should also run on Microsoft Windows. I mainly develop on Slackware Linux, and test on other systems periodically, so there is a chance that some problems will creep in between tests.
content.h3: What do I do if it doesn't compile?
How do I make it run automatically when the machine boots?
content.p: On UNIX-like systems, this usually involves tinkering about in /etc/rc.d, though it is probably best to consult your system's documentation beforehand.
